definition: to blow/to play a wind instrument/to blast/to puff/to boast/to brag/to end in failure/to fall through

sentences.english: The leaders of the city always boast that the city is the most suitable place for human beings to live.
sentences.chinese: 海口市当局总是吹嘘这个城市最适合人类居住。

sentences.english: His boasting cost him his life,after all.
sentences.chinese: 他的吹嘘最终以他的生命为代价。

sentences.english: He bragged that his father was the most successful businessman in the city.
sentences.chinese: 他吹嘘他父亲是本市最成功的商人。

sentences.english: My boss is a stuffed shirt, bragging all the time.
sentences.chinese: 我的老板神气十足，整天在吹嘘。

sentences.english: The Bolivarian leader's vaunted popularity tumbles.
sentences.chinese: 委内瑞拉玻利瓦尔共和国领导人所吹嘘的声望猛跌。

sentences.english: The solid rampart surrounded by moats boast as a iron-case with slab basements and bricks walls.
sentences.chinese: 天堑固垒并被吹嘘为铁案板坯地下室墙壁和砖头。

sentences.english: I wish he would stop crowing about his examination results.
sentences.chinese: 我多么希望他不再吹嘘他的考试成绩。

sentences.english: The big story was the stabilization in the bank's loan portfolios.
sentences.chinese: 最值得吹嘘的是该行稳定的贷款业务量。

sentences.english: Exporting TV dramas is just one way for Koreans to shamelessly promote themselves.
sentences.chinese: 出口韩剧也是韩国人无耻自我吹嘘的一个途径。

sentences.english: Willoughby's boast of his implacable character was to blame.
sentences.chinese: 威洛比吹嘘过他不饶人的性格，他应该受到谴责。

sentences.english: Stop blowing your own horn before me. I know you very well.
sentences.chinese: 别在我面前自我吹嘘，我非常了解你。

sentences.english: He always bragged about1 his strength.
sentences.chinese: 他总是吹嘘自己力大无比。

sentences.english: Tom constantly brags about how well he plays table tennis.
sentences.chinese: 汤姆老是吹嘘他的乒乓球打得多好。

sentences.english: Don't blow your own horn. If you do something praiseworthy, someone will eventually notice.
sentences.chinese: 别自我吹嘘，你所做的有价值的事，别人终会知道。

sentences.english: The magazines can tout this or that tiny
sentences.chinese: 杂志上都在吹嘘这样那样的当季女包。

definition: to talk big/to shoot off one's mouth/to chat (dialect)
to show off/to make a display of
to boast/to shoot one's mouth off
to rock/to sway/to flicker (e.g. of lights reflected on water)/to flutter (e.g. of a flag)/to trick sb into doing sth/to dupe/to con
